body:
@gianm I thought in all the cases druid wanted to setup number of reducers itself (e.g. IndexGeneratorJob sets the number of reducers but will get overridden by user setting and can potentially cause indexing to faile e.g. if the users sets the number to 0).
If user overriding num reducers is a genuine usecase then this PR is unnecessary and can be closed.

@himanshug in that case how do you feel about moving the "addJobProperties" step to right after "injectSystemProperties" for all the hadoop jobs? Currently it's a lot later than that, which does seem like a bug, since it means you can overwrite things that are explicitly set in the code (and we probably don't want to allow that).

The groupByJob in DeterminePartitionsJob does not explicitly set a number of reducers, so it does need some way to set it. I think for most people it's going to use whatever they have in their mapred-site.xml.
@gianm sounds like in some cases we do want user to be able to specify num reducers so I will just update IndexGeneratorJob to not allow overrides.
I think i have addressed all the comments
@gianm @fjy changed PR to let user properties added first and then by druid code so that stuff is picked up from user but overridden by druid (if necessary)
Will merge after travis
this broke for real, not a spurious test failure this time :(
@drcrallen is there an automated way of generating backport PRs or is this created manually with specific commits cherry-picked?
@himanshug cherry-picked.
@gianm Backport failed >.<   #1690
@xvrl Problem in test, not code
@fjy crazy week; added default & link, and signed CLA.

I wrote some code towards this as part of segment metadata work in #1609 but separated it from that PR and made that contain only essential segment metadata that was required for that PR, so that code sits on my machine.
But, If we store QueryGranularity in the segment metadata and two segments are merged/appended, what should be the QueryGranularity of that final segment for example in the case of AppendTask ?

IMO the LCM of the underlying granularities makes sense, as that's all that we can guarantee will be available for queries.

This can get weird if we have funky granularities, but I think that's ok since at least it's honest. Like, if we have one segment with queryGranularity DAY - Los_Angeles and one with queryGranularity DAY - UTC then the LCM is ALL.
I don't think we should ever destroy data on merge / append. We could also simply not merge things that have incompatible granularities, or default to NONE, and leave it to the user at query time.

hmm, maybe we should discuss how we expect people to use this metadata and decide based on that.

I was thinking that the QueryGranularity metadata would be used by UIs so they could use it to decide which queryGranularities to use without needing to be preconfigured by the user. For that I think the LCM is reasonable- you wouldn't want to offer hourly granularity queries on an interval that has mixed hour granularity and day granularity.

Using NONE is gonna make the logic for a UI kind of messy, since they'll think millisecond granularity is available.

I think it's ok to avoid automatic merges of incompatible granularities, but IMO it should be possible for a user to ask for a merge of two segments with incompatible granularities.
I think if we store NONE it wouldn't actually be useful for much. Maybe that is a failure of imagination, thoughâ€¦
@gianm I typed my comment w/o seeing yours. but anyway, Given that there is no intelligent way to combine QueryGranularity, how will things like coordinator merge work ?

I have created a document at https://docs.google.com/document/d/1PUG3crI2jiPa_u926R0KrkZVM7t706rXp1IuUxVXB5E/edit?usp=sharing to capture various design details of kafka/tranquility ingestion work . This has been created with inputs from @gianm and still under active development. feel free to discuss here.

@himanshug when you're actually doing a merge, you can always just use NONE for the indexing- it doesn't matter what's in the underlying segments. But storing NONE in the metadata is not really useful if you want it to represent what is actually usefully queryable.

Fwiw I think it would be fine for now to leave QueryGranularity out of the metadata, and ask users to "know" what it should be. Having the aggregators in there is the real win since it makes automatic reindexing possible.

@gianm my concern with updating query granularity at merge time would be to cause downstream queries to return different results after a merge than they did before if the goal is to expose the query granularity to the client.

@xvrl yeah, I agree that's kind of weird. I think we could probably do one of these to make it less weird,

1) potentially include multiple queryGranularities per segment; split up by interval. When the merge process merges segments that don't all cover the same interval, it can faithfully represent what's there in different areas of the timeline. Users would presumably already have some code to handled different queryGranularities on different parts of the timeline, since different segments could have different queryGranularities.

2) don't include queryGranularities, establish an expectation that it's the user's problem.

Even if we do (1) we still have the potential to throw away information (when two segments for the same interval have different granularities) but I think that's ok. If you merge a queryGranularity = HOUR segment with a queryGranularity = DAY segment and the intervals overlap, then the resulting segment really should represent itself as DAY.

Done second scan of review comments. Added unit tests that covers most workflow.
@fjy @xvrl @drcrallen @himanshug @gianm @nishantmonu51 @cheddar

@cheddar @b-slim please remember to squash before merging
otherwise it makes it hard to backport fixes, cherry-pick, or investigate regressions, because of the way commits are ordered.

@cheddar @guobingkun given that we are removing existing configuration options, and are not fully backwards compatible, i.e. changing the way most users have to deploy Druid, should we bump version up to 0.9 after merging this?

Cool, I'm :+1:  after travis
@nishantmonu51 I couldn't find a good way to do that.
I think timeseries still zero fills and groupBy still does not.
Timeseries should not be zero-filling anymore. We've fixed issues around that a while back.

Ok, it does zero-fill by default, but I forgot about the skipEmptyBuckets thing that turns it off. I think I can be forgiven for that since it's not documented :)

I'll write some docs for it, but also wonder if it would make sense to change the default behavior in the future. I think zero-filling would be better off by default.

I  made some changes to make sure the tarball still works,
1. Added an exec plugin so that `mvn clean install` will generate all the extensions directories, there will be a `druid_extensions` directory that contains all the extensions (except `mysql-metadata-storage`) in the tarball.
2. Added another assembly step so that `mysql-metadata-storage` will be packaged in a separate tarball. User can go into `druid_extensions` and untar `mysql-metadata-storage--bin.tar.gz` there.
3. Modified common runtime properties so that the extension load list still contains `druid-examples`,`druid-kafka-eight`
4. Removed extension-distribution since it is replaced by extension directoies.
5. Updated tutorial, firewall and Build From Source docs.
6. Include hadoop dependencies in the tarball. Modified "loading batch data" tutorial so that user doesn't need to configure hadoop classpath for overlord.
@fjy @xvrl @gianm @drcrallen @nishantmonu51 @himanshug @cheddar
Forgot to mention I also updated Build From Source doc. Now `mvn clean install` generates the tarballs.

@zengzhihai110 :)

The biggest problems with handoff generally pertain to misconfiguration. What deep storage are you using? How is it being set up?

I think it's ok to let people set their own priorities. I don't think it's necessary but I think it's ok if we want to go that way.

About exclusivity- I don't see why we need non-exclusive locks. Why not invalidate all lower priority locks when a higher priority request comes in? There still needs to be some method that upgrades a lock to non-preemptible, but I _think_ it would be okay to have them always be exclusive. That should make life simpler in the lockbox.

Btw, I get confused talking about "higher" and "lower" priority when smaller-numbered priorities are higherâ€¦
@drcrallen are we intentionally not making ServerManager like updates for the broker so that broker also report same metric?
LGTM (after Travis)

@gianm LockUpgradeAction is the mechanism using which lock can become non-preemptible or "exclusive". And yes when a higher priority task comes in and all the other conflicting tasks have lower priority non-exclusive(non-preemptive) locks then all the lower priority locks will be revoked, see [this](https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/1679/files#diff-f703e7f655ddebdbd0544caa89455da4R362). Thus, the lower priority tasks will fail eventually. So, if I understood your comment correctly it is doing exactly the same thing what you have mentioned. Am I missing something ? 
Yes...the higher priority have lower number, it is like a ranking system. I can change it if it is not intuitive .
LGTM (after Travis)
@gianm and one more thing - what is your preference about making priority a part of context https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/1604 ?
bouncing for travis

@gianm pls see this when you can, it is the continuation to discussion in  #1682

This would be very useful. It's not possible for me to choose a granularity ahead of time because my timeseries data is filtered and spans an unknown part of the data source. As it is I have to make multiple calls to druid with increasing granularity to find the start and end time.
@himanshug Not in this PR. The appropriate runner could be wrapped at the broker level using the same approach but I purposefully left it out of this PR to limit the scope.
It's pretty standard to leave defaults commented out with explanation. Is there a reason they need uncommmented?
Ok, this one seems to be in a good state now.
Closing in favor of https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/1696
@nishantmonu51 I updated this PR to use your Task context
Sorry, I made this pull not intentionally.

if you are looking for the location of runtime.properties is to be added to the classpath of middlemanager. 
If you are looking for a sample prod configs - you can find them here - http://druid.io/docs/latest/configuration/production-cluster.html

@gianm I took care of your comments. I have a question though, the integration test that I wrote submits 3 Index task with different priorities in order such that only last one with highest priority succeeds as the last one will revoke the tasklocks of first two. However, sometimes after the last task succeeds, ExecutorLifeCycle for one of the first two tasks will start and it calls `isReady` for that task again [here](https://github.com/druid-io/druid/blob/master/indexing-service/src/main/java/io/druid/indexing/worker/executor/ExecutorLifecycle.java#L120). Thus, the task will acquire the lock again as the last task with highest priority has already succeeded. Do you think it is correct behavior and it can succeed or once the lock for a task is revoked it should always fail ?  
I was just thinking why there is a call to `isReady` again in ExecutorLifeCyle, wouldn't for all tasks (even in local mode) the taskqueue will ensure that the task is ready before running it using the task runner. There's a comment saying "Won't hurt in remote mode, and is required for setting up locks in local mode:" I don't understand why it is required in local mode. What am I missing here ? BTW I removed the `isReady` call in ExecutorLifeCycle and ran it through our CI pipeline (which runs integration test as well) and it passed.

No, Its not necessary to use indexing-service, you can directly spawn realtime nodes.

The `isReady` call in ExecutorLifeCycle was introduced in this commit - https://github.com/druid-io/druid/commit/70c153592f049cb7d975bc255b42a4f12f547819
